Award.AwardTitle: Gene regulation in response to heat stress

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the mechanisms that allow organisms to survive after exposure to high temperatures. Using baker's yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae), experiments will focus on understanding how cells coordinate genome-wide changes in gene expression following heat stress. Because the heat stress response is evolutionarily conserved, research using yeast as the model is expected to provide insights into the fundamental mechanisms employed in more complex organisms. Additional broader impacts of this research include the training of two graduate students and summer research opportunities for three high school biology teachers from a school district with a large, underrepresented minority population.

The dynamic regulation of stress-responsive genes is critical for viability of all eukaryotes. In S. cerevisiae, the gene-specific and evolutionarily conserved activator, Heat Shock Factor 1 (Hsf1), plays a central role in stimulating both basal and induced transcription of HSP genes. These genes encode molecular chaperones that are critical for maintaining protein homeostasis and in combating proteotoxic stress. Whether Hsf1 is also responsible for the global down-regulation of non-HSP gene expression following exposure to thermal stress is unknown. Aim 1 employs chromatin immunoprecipitation combined with deep sequencing (ChIP-seq) to investigate genome-wide occupancy of Hsf1 under both non-stressful and stressful conditions, and determine the activator's role in directing the genome-wide occupancy of Mediator, a central coactivator and signal integrator of Pol II transcription. In addition, comparative dynamic transcriptome analysis will be used to measure global transcription rates and correlate these with genome-wide Hsf1, Mediator and Pol II occupancy. Aim 2 employs chromosome conformation capture techniques to characterize the in vivo conformation and nuclear organization of Hsf1-regulated genes under both non-inducing and heat shock-inducing conditions. A key goal is to solidify evidence that HSP genes loop, 'crumple' (accordion-style) and coalesce into transcriptionally active foci following exposure of cells to heat shock, and determine the kinetics with which they form and dissipate looped DNA structures. Additionally, through use of looping, crumpling and coalescence-deficient mutants, the biological significance of these phenomena will be explored. Results are expected to advance understanding of how gene regulatory changes enable cell survival following heat stress.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the laboratory of David Gross investigated how an evolutionarily conserved protein, Heat Shock Factor 1 (Hsf1), found in virtually all organisms from yeast to humans, helps protect cells from potentially devastating damage caused by cell exposure to stresses elicited by heat, toxic chemicals, oxidizing agents or heavy metals. These stresses share in common the fact that they damage cellular proteins by causing them to misfold.  Misfolded proteins can cause cell death or lead to other serious consequences, including cancer or neurodegenerative disease.  To reverse the damage to typical proteins caused by such stress exposure, our cells make specialized proteins, termed Heat Shock Proteins (HSPs), that have the ability to repair the damage incurred.  Yet how the rapid synthesis of these life-saving HSPs is accomplished is not fully understood.  It is known, however, that the initial step involves Hsf1, a nuclear protein that binds to the DNA of HSP genes and elicits their transcriptional activation (copying of HSP gene DNA into messenger RNA). Yet how Hsf1 finds the HSP genes, which represent <1% of all genes and are dispersed archipelago-like across individual chromosomes, is not well understood. 

Here we used the model organism, bakers yeast (Saccharomyces cerevisiae), to (i) map where in the genome Hsf1 binds; (ii) how Hsf1 locates its target HSP genes; and (iii) what changes in gene structure and three-dimensional nuclear location take place in HSP genes, when cells are exposed to thermal stress.  We found that a physiological heat stress (30 to 39 C temperature shift) triggered the rapid DNA binding of Hsf1 to ~80 locations (loci) across the yeast genome.  These occupied loci were arrayed across 14 of the 16 chromosomes, and were associated with 50 genes that were similarly arrayed across most chromosomes. The transcription of these genes (many but not all of which encode HSPs), was strongly dependent on DNA-bound Hsf1.  Quite unexpectedly, we observed that Hsf1-regulated HSP genes underwent profound changes in their conformation upon transcriptional activation: they crumpled, pretzel-like, as a consequence of induced physical contacts between the beginning, middle and end of each gene.  Crumpling of this magnitude had not been reported before - in any organism.  These structural changes were evident within 1 min following exposure to heat, peaked within 2.5 min, and began to dissipate within 30-60 min.  Most intriguing, HSP gene conformational changes were accompanied by their dynamic repositioning within the nucleus, as they coalesced into 4-5 discrete foci, and in parallel with gene crumpling, did so quite rapidly (within 1 - 2 min).  Also similar to crumpling, interchromosomal interactions between HSP genes were evanescent, and typically attenuated within 30 min. While we do not understand how HSP gene coalescence happens (or why), we do know that it is orchestrated by Hsf1, and is highly specific to Hsf1-regulated genes. Interestingly, we obtained evidence that this coalescence may reflect a liquid-liquid phase-separation of Hsf1-regulated genes from the remainder of the genome (i.e., from the other 5000 genes).  If the case, then yeast HSP genes may bear a resemblance to key cell-identity genes in human cells whose massive regulatory regions (termed super enhancers) have recently been shown to likewise undergo a phase separation from the rest of the genome within the human nucleus.

Broader impacts of this project included the training of four Ph.D. graduate students and a postdoctoral scholar.  The project also provided a summer research internship for a high school biology teacher located in a rural school district in northwest Louisiana, with a large, underrepresented minority population.
